natural problem: Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form.
natural solution: The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.

The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.

After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 40 * (2 * sqrt(3) + 4) * 6"
shows  "d = 480 + 480 * sqrt(3)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes d :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 40 * (2 * sqrt(3) + 4) * 6"
shows  "d = 480 + 480 * sqrt(3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the value of $d$ which is equal to $40*(2*\sqrt{3} + 4)*6$. The final answer is $480 + 480*\sqrt{3}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes circle_radius :: real
assumes h0 : "circle_radius = 40"
and h1 : "6 * (card {A,B,C,D,E,F} :: ('a set)) * (\<lambda>points. dist points) = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
shows  "least_distance_traveled = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. theorem
fixes circle_radius :: real
assumes h0 : "circle_radius = 40"
and h1 : "6 * (card {A,B,C,D,E,F} :: ('a set)) * (\<lambda>points. dist points) = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
shows  "least_distance_traveled = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A person walks around a circle with a radius of 40 units, visiting six points (A, B, C, D, E, and F) in a specific order. The total distance traveled by the person is 480 + 480 * sqrt(3) units. What is the least distance they traveled?

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes radius distance :: real
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>i = 1..n. 2 * (n - 1 - i) * (radius * cos (pi / n)))"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"

theorem
fixes radius distance :: real
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>i = 1..n. 2 * (n - 1 - i) * (radius * cos (pi / n)))"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A regular hexagon has a side length of 40 units. Find the sum of the lengths of all the diagonals in the hexagon. The final answer is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r d :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "r = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> n \<longrightarrow> d i = sum (\<lambda> j. 2 * r * sqrt (2 - 2 * cos (2 * pi * real (j) / real (n)))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> n - 1 \<and> j \<noteq> i - 1 \<and> j \<noteq> i \<and> j \<noteq> i + 1}"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 1..n. d i) = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes r d :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "r = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> n \<longrightarrow> d i = sum (\<lambda> j. 2 * r * sqrt (2 - 2 * cos (2 * pi * real (j) / real (n)))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> n - 1 \<and> j \<noteq> i - 1 \<and> j \<noteq> i \<and> j \<noteq> i + 1}"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 1..n. d i) = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
A regular hexagon has 6 sides, and each side has a length of 40 units. There are 6 diagonals in the hexagon. Calculate the total length of all the diagonals, given that the length of a diagonal, $d_i$, can be calculated as the sum of $2r\sqrt{2-2\cos( rac{2\pi j}{n})}$ for all $j$ such that $1 \leq j \leq n - 1$ and $j 
eq i-1$, $j 
eq i$, $j 
eq i+1$. The final answer is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes radius :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "let boys = 6; handshakes = (boys * (boys - 3)) div 2 in handshakes = 9"
and h2 : "let distance_between_adjacent_boys = 2 * radius * sin (pi / boys) in distance_between_adjacent_boys = 80 / 3"
and h3 : "let distance = 3 * (radius * (sqrt 3) + 2 * radius) in distance = 480 + 480 * (sqrt 3)"
shows  "h3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes radius :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "let boys = 6; handshakes = (boys * (boys - 3)) div 2 in handshakes = 9"
and h2 : "let distance_between_adjacent_boys = 2 * radius * sin (pi / boys) in distance_between_adjacent_boys = 80 / 3"
and h3 : "let distance = 3 * (radius * (sqrt 3) + 2 * radius) in distance = 480 + 480 * (sqrt 3)"
shows  "h3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Six boys are standing on the circumference of a circle with a radius of 40. They shake hands with each other, but only if they are not adjacent. There are a total of 9 handshakes. Calculate the following:

1. The distance between two adjacent boys on the circle.
2. The total distance the boys travel if each boy moves to the position of the boy who is 3 positions away (clockwise or counterclockwise) along the circle's circumference.

The final answers are:
1. The distance between two adjacent boys is $\frac{80}{3}$.
2. The total distance the boys travel is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes radius :: real
and n :: nat
and distance :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>k\<in>{1,2,3,4,5,6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{i. i \<noteq> k \<and> i \<noteq> (k + 1) mod n \<and> i \<noteq> (k - 1) mod n}. 2 * radius * abs(sin(pi * (i - k) / n))))"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes radius :: real
and n :: nat
and distance :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>k\<in>{1,2,3,4,5,6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{i. i \<noteq> k \<and> i \<noteq> (k + 1) mod n \<and> i \<noteq> (k - 1) mod n}. 2 * radius * abs(sin(pi * (i - k) / n))))"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A regular hexagon has 6 sides. The distance between each non-adjacent vertex is twice the radius of the circumscribed circle. If the radius of the circumscribed circle is 40, find the sum of the distances between all non-adjacent vertices. The final answer is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance :: real and radius :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..n}. (k - 1) * (n - k)) * (2 * radius) + (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..n}. ((n - 1) div 2) * (n - 1)) * (radius * sqrt 3)"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes distance :: real and radius :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "distance = (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..n}. (k - 1) * (n - k)) * (2 * radius) + (\<Sum>k \<in> {1..n}. ((n - 1) div 2) * (n - 1)) * (radius * sqrt 3)"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A hexagon is formed by placing regular hexagons of side length 40 units each side by side. Find the distance between two opposite vertices of this large hexagon. The final answer is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes radius :: real
and total_distance :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "total_distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
shows  "least_distance_walked_by_six_boys radius = total_distance"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes radius :: real
and total_distance :: real
assumes h0 : "radius = 40"
and h1 : "total_distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
shows  "least_distance_walked_by_six_boys radius = total_distance"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Six boys start at the same point on the circumference of a circle with a radius of 40 units. They each walk along the circumference in equal distances until they return to their starting point. The total distance walked by all six boys is $480 + 480\sqrt{3}$ units. Find the least distance walked by each boy.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys :: nat and radius :: real and distance :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 6"
and h1 : "radius = 40"
and h2 : "distance = 2 * radius * (boys - 1) + (4 * radius * sqrt 3)"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes boys :: nat and radius :: real and distance :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 6"
and h1 : "radius = 40"
and h2 : "distance = 2 * radius * (boys - 1) + (4 * radius * sqrt 3)"
shows  "distance = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that there are 6 boys and each boy is 40 meters away from the center of a circle, calculate the total distance travelled if each boy moves to the position of the next boy in a clockwise direction. The final distance is $480 + 480 \sqrt{3}$ meters.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r n d :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "d = n * (n - 3) / 2 * r * (1 + sqrt 3)"
shows  "d = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six boys stood equally spaced on a circle of radius 40 feet. Each boy walked to all of the other non-adjacent persons on the circle, shook their hands and then returned to his original spot on the circle before the next boy started his trip to shake hands with all of the other non-adjacent boys on the circle. After all six boys had done this, what is the least distance in feet that could have been traveled? Express your answer in simplest radical form. The final Answer is 480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}
 ### Proof
 The thicker solid line in the diagram shows the shortest path that one person could travel. The circle is equally divided into six 60-degree arcs, so the short distance is 40 feet, the same as a radius.
 The dotted line is a diameter that separates the quadrilateral into two 30-60-90 triangles. The longer leg is $(80\sqrt {3})/2$, or $40\sqrt{3}$ feet. Each person travels $40\sqrt{3} + 40 + 40 + 40\sqrt{3} = 80 + 80\sqrt{3}$ feet.
 After all six people did this, $6(80 + 80\sqrt{3}) = \boxed{480 + 480\sqrt{3}\text{ feet}}$ had been traveled. [asy] import olympiad; import geometry; size(100); defaultpen(linewidth(0.8)); dotfactor=4;
 draw(unitcircle); for(int i = 0; i <= 6; ++i){ dot(dir(60*i + 30)); } draw(dir(30)--dir(90)--dir(150)--dir(270)--cycle); draw(dir(90)--dir(270),dotted); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes r n d :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 40"
and h1 : "n = 6"
and h2 : "d = n * (n - 3) / 2 * r * (1 + sqrt 3)"
shows  "d = 480 + 480 * sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A circle with radius 40 is divided into 6 sectors. Each sector is then used to form a cone. Find the total surface area of all the cones if it is given by the formula $d = n * (n - 3) / 2 * r * (1 + \sqrt{3})$. The final answer is $480 + 480 * \sqrt{3}$.
